title: Real-Time Information Processing

author: Dunja Mladenić, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute
Marko Grobelnik, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: So the presentation is about real time information processing and it's a result of collaboration joint work with my colleague Marco Global Nick and its intention is to support people thinking about FP7 proposals on intelligent information management.
So let's see briefly outline of the presentation.
First, we'll look into Motivation Y to do real time information processing, then a brief introduction who is doing what.
A little bit about approach is not really technical.
For examples, applications, and then some future.
Challenges and for the references you can look into if you want to hear more details.
So for motivation, why one would need real time information processing?

It's in this situation where you have a problem that you're adressing where time and reaction speed actually are important, and I important because in many situations they do correlate with many target quantities.

For instance, if we have Stock Exchange, then they correlate with earnings or in the situation if we have controlling and we have device that we control, there really correlate with quality of service.
If there is a failing device, it really depends on our reaction speed in.
Repairing or replacing the device.
What is quality of our service?
Or in fraud detection, they correlate with safety.
So in general, real time information processing would be needed and applied when we have situations where reaction speed brings value, and then if our system reacts faster than it creates new.
Value.
So who is doing that?
Who works on that area a basically there are at least two research groups.
Research areas that deal with real time information processing.

One is 3 mining, which is a subfield of data mining and its deal with mining data streams in different scenarios and the methods and algorithms are connected to machine learning and also databases and the other one is complex event processing which actually also does a lot of work.

On the analysis on theory in the sense of causality between events, if we have lower level events, we would like to figure out what a higher level events, complex events and also basically based also on the data and inference in statistics.
And you can read more about the boat.
In the short descriptions on Wikipedia.
So what is it?
How does it look?
How is the structure of a system for real time information processing?
What do we have?
Is a set of approaches which are enabling operations on the stream of data on which we get from surrounding.
So there is reality and there are events which we capture in some way and transforming the format which is needed and appropriate for whatever modeling we want to do.
And then based on the model.
Generally we can do query segmentation prediction.

Depends what we want and this this is the kind of underlying architecture, but depending on how really real time critical your application is, some of these parts can be merged or some of them can be even pushed into hardware into graphical processing units.
So if it's really time critical that you optimize access to the database and operations.
Eat.
So what are the approaches when we're dealing with stream and it's really problem to hand to handle the stream?
It's because there is a data intensive data stream, so it's a large amount of data that is coming.
Or maybe it's coming very quickly and also what we want at the end.
With this data we want to perform some complex operations.
So situation is such that there is high volume of data.
And we can't store this data, just somewhere offline and then do something later so we can go through the data.
Basically only once.
And also the data is changing overtime.
We can't count that the data is going to be about the same and followed the same properties as a month ago or a year ago.
So on the top of approximation what we do is also adaptation of our model of the way how we store the data.
So the typical solution in real time information processing is not to store the data explicitly, but rather store it in some aggregated format in some model, and which model are we going to use?
Depends on what we want to do at the end with the data.
For instance, there are algorithms for in machine learning.
For years there are algorithms for online learning, like we know or perceptron and what they do.
They basically store just a model and the model is such that when you get new stream of new data, you can easily update the model, throw the data away and just keep the model.
And like for perceptron, model is just a vector of numbers.
So we have like much smaller amount of data.
And what we are storing in.
So what the typical application?
Usually they are kind of mission critical, so we have this intensive data stream and complex queries which we want to do on the top.
So here are a few examples.
For instance dynamic tracking of stock fluctuations.
Or surveillance for fraud and money laundering.
Or if we have a network of some devices or data communication network and we want to do traffic monitoring.
Or if there is a center net sensor network and we want to do analysis on that sensor networks or if there is a website and we have many users so there is a log file which is growing through time.
There is this stream of data clickstream and we want to do web clickstream analysis or for instance power consumption measurement.
So in the next 4 slides will just go through some applications just to make.
More concrete as examples.
So one application on stock monitoring.
What do we have?
There is input.
There is a stock of price stream of stock prices and there is sale volumes and it comes over time and we want to do some technical analysis or chart charting and support trading decisions.
So these are some of the examples of complex queries that we may want to do on that kind of data.
So it's something like notify me when the price of IBM is about some value.
And the first time Microsoft Price is below the other value or notify me when the price of any stock increases monotonic monotonically for over 30 minutes.
Or for instance, this example notify me whenever there is a double top formation in the price of any stock.
In general, this kind of queries is supported in the prototype system.
There's a prototype from Stanford that was that is developed by not, but they are not really supported in.
Of the.
Shelves databases the other application example is telecommunication network monitoring, where we have Tele communication network of devices.
This is a concrete example of the system which is used in British Telecom.
It's about 25,000 different devices and they issue alarms.
If there is some problems.
So there is alarm server to which they send alarm.
And this life feed of data of alarms which is incoming goes into alarm Explorer service.
Which does analysis and offers.

Among offers analysis of the data to the operator, which is in one way analysis and also offers some top predictions on the big board display where it is really important to see what is prediction about future alarms.
So basically there are three real time scenarios which are supported.
One is root cause analysis.

That's the situation when there is alarm and many devices actually issue an alarm and you want to see which is the root cause where the alarm started, which is the first device that issues the alarms and then.
You know, in the second you have like a domino effect.

All the many devices issuing alarm or short term 4th prediction where you want to predict based on the previous data of the situation of network and incoming situation, which device may be issuing in alarm in the next 15 minutes or a lot of long-term anomaly detection where you want to see if there is some pattern occurring which may lead later to alarm issuing an just to trigger.
To a person to bring that on the screen to just 4.
King so another application which is not so the time critical, but however it does include time.
It's online advertising and that's again a concrete application for New York Times, where the idea is to observe micro trends.

And what is given a log file so New York time has this website with articles, an archive of articles actually from 1851 on till today and there is a log file and this log file of people visiting the website is about 100 million page clicks per day.
So there is intensive volume of data and it's coming over time and based on combining that stream of clicks and content we can build a profile of users that are coming to the website.
And then with this stream of profiles can be.
As used as input in a system for trend detection.
And based on that, the system actually identifies what are the trends and what are the segments.
And maybe maybe with time there can be a new segments coming on.
Segments can be something like people interested in health, so they are reading about diabetes, heart disease, heart illness and so on.
Or people interested in green energy reading about hybrid cars, energy profile, power and so on.
So why is that interesting?
If we identify some emerging new segment then the sales people?
Can actually go out and try to sell this segment saying I have this new segment on green Energy and go to advertisers and say you know I'm going to pay me more than just for random person.
If I can show your ads to this particular group of people right?
And this is actually turns out to be very important for them and can raise up the price of advertising.
Actually for factor of 10 or 100 that the advertisers are prepared to pay hundred time mores.
For showing ads to a targeted so.
Payment of people and the 4th example of application on topic tracking.
Again, this one maybe is not so time critical, but however it does include time.
It's a time which is included in news published in New York Times Archive.
This is a particular example and you want to put some queries on the top of that query, such as.
This is an example of Clinton, so we ask in the data from August 1996 to August 1997.

What are all the news where Clinton was mentioned and we get the the answer back and also visualization of that overtime and all the news are analyzed into clusters based on topics and then you can see that like through US election time, the topic, the orange topic on election is growing.
But at the point of election themselves they just drops down.
And then it's maybe a little bit commenting on election.
But basically you's budget is the one which is speaking up and so on.
So.
If we go just go for future challenges.
I already mentioned actually that this stream operations on databases complex of corpus operation are not part of standard database systems.
They are however there in prototypes, so one of the challenges is to integrate it into database systems.
The other one is dealing with stream of complex events where you actually don't have nice organized, structured events.

But maybe documents are happening or some other less structured data and you want to do analysis on the top of that or the challenge of handling dynamic social networks when actually this is one of the hot research topics in data mining.
When the underlining model, which is changing overtime, is actually graph and has now done some content, for instance like email exchange, people are sending emails to each other.

There is some contact, a content, textual content, images flow going through that graph and then there are connections of the people and this whole social network shaking is changing overtime or messengers or phone call records.
So all these go into dynamic social networks or semantic stream analysis.
It's also how to map some lower level.
Stream events into higher level semantic concepts.
For instance, in sensor network there is a particular application addressed in one of European projects called Lark about real Time City, where there is a city.
It's a in Milan that has sensors all over the city measuring some lower level quantities and you want to get on higher level understanding what is happening and what are the events in there.
And I'm sure there are many more challenges there.

Research challenges that people are addressing, how to model, how to make your algorithms more efficient, how to bring results of stream data mining to mobile devices when there is a challenge of visualization, when there is a challenge of minimizing battery consumption and so on.
So there are many challenges is hot topic, and there are books.
These are just some of the examples or available on Amazon and they address different topics like going from topics connected to.
Data management stream data management.
Management of large amount of data.
Upcoming overtime going into models and algorithms where there is also a theory behind on how to make things sufficient stream mining sensor networks of stream event processing complexes.

Processing and if anyone is interested into reading a little bit more on this area, seats on Wikipedia on the on three mining convention complex event processing, but also closely related errors like real time computing online algorithms already mentioned, worst case analysis, and probably some more.
And otherwise you can also check some of the tutorials which go more into technical details.

The two I'm showing here available on video lectures portal which has over 6000 different lectures, mainly from the area of data mining, machine learning, semantic web and these two tutorials are there as well.
So you're all invited to check there and see a little bit more.
And basically that's it just briefly about real time information processing that I want to discuss.
So actually I think I can take some questions if there are questions or any feedback you want to put.
At the point.
Yeah.
OK. Well.
OK if not then.
